speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
transcript: Okay maybe maybe I'll start. I'll take the second part of the question which is on how can their discovery and optimization be accelerated. I think electrochemistry in terms of a discipline is one where progress has been extraordinarily slow, which is because of the fact that it's a very complex system, many interacting components, needing learning, and by learning I mean you do some experiment or you do some simulation and you want to answer some hypothesis, right? And often the ratio of the number of number of experiments or number of simulations run to test a hypothesis is very very high. And that has to do with the fact that getting high quality data is very difficult. So I think here I think there's going to be a significant advancement possible especially in this sort of very complex space of CO2 where you have many different control variables, many different design variables. So I think robotic experimentation and machine learning I think is going to fundamentally alter this this space and it's going to be a frontier that electrochemistry could be very well positioned to to spearhead because a lot of the setups that we need actually are conducive for being able to do automated experiments and may not require like human handling and so on. Like doing things with like robotic arms and so on is much harder than being able to automate like flow through type setups. So I think that that aspect I think could be one that I feel very passionately about as sort of the next frontier for electrochemistry.

speaker: Jenny Yang
transcript: Yeah, so I totally agree with Venkat. The process right now for catalyst discovery is slow. We focus a lot in our group on trying to understand the mechanism and pathways to figure out which are the key steps because oftentimes selectivity for example is determined at some common intermediate that can either react with protons or CO for example and that sort of dictates what happens in the rest of the reaction. So I think I'm very in favor of using machine learning to help us discover catalysts but I think right now in some cases we don't know what the question is if that makes sense. Like what are the key bond making breaking steps what are the key intermediates in different reaction pathways that we need to understand in order to innovate selectivity. And for the first question which is about novel materials and electrode architecture I have two thoughts on that and one is that transport for capture is important because it's dilute and that's something I didn't appreciate until I started talking to engineers. And then the other thing is that can we design architectures that can do cascades because the more I do catalyst design I realize that it's hard to optimize a single catalyst to go through several steps but if you can optimize a sequence of them and then organize them then that could be a way to get better selectivity.

speaker: Caleb Hill
transcript: Yeah I mean just to add into that point about setting up cascades and stuff I mean one this is one reason that looking beyond kind of the classic well-characterized electrode materials onto things that are you know kind of poly-elemental possibly and carry a variety of different distinct catalytic sites that could set up that sort of cascade is really attractive but that also presents an even harder characterization problem and kind of throughput problem because once you have a more complicated material structure composition it becomes harder to tune and kind of evaluate things independently. So again that that kind of machine learning approach could greatly help.

speaker: Pratik Dholabhai
transcript: Yeah I I echo with what is said by Venkat and Caleb and what I would say is machine learning definitely can help a lot of times if you are trying to grasp a better understanding of some of the chemistries which are you know the more complex the material it becomes more challenging even from a theoretical standpoint. Throughput computing combined with you know machine learning or trying to understand you know what targeted properties we are looking for. For example a lot of good electrocatalysts are available right. We also want to make sure is there a route to also find cost effective materials. For example platinum is not going to be the only answer every time for instance we try to do something like this. Quite famously the system here it works well but we are not going to sequester carbon dioxide using platinum. So that's where probably machine learning or you know modeling can also work with experiment to try to optimize. And I think that that could be really challenging but I think it's it's a fascinating route to follow actually.

speaker: Adam Holewinski
transcript: So I'll I'll toss one more idea out there for the as long as we're on the machine learning topic but that is in process integration. So you know in in all of these cases we need to run our oxidations opposite reductions and so you need to think about compatible reactions that are going to run on similar scales and you know basically how to sort of match match your chemistries so that we're not doing you know if we're doing a reduction do we really just want to make O2 at the other electrode or do we want to incorporate some value added oxidation and what are the logistics and kind of what what reactions or combinations of reactions that we we choose to pair with with a larger scale one.

We don't always have the experimental means or the you know power to keep refining all those things right but at the same time we can have a effort even targeted just to something which has not done just like you know some materials which have never been thought about for you know electrocatalysis. speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
transcript: I don't necessarily know if there they we have a lot of meetings, but I don't know if there's really a good meeting that like if you think about the North American Catalysis Society meeting, which is the biggest meeting in the heterogeneous world, like electrocatalysis is hardly welcome there. And then ECS, you know, I think generally doesn't have too much heterogeneous catalysis. So, so I think there's not it's not clear that there's an easy bridge to be to be formed. And I think, you know, I guess, you know, in terms of communities, I think it's it's not they see it as competing, right? I mean, I think it's it's a little like batteries versus fuel cells, right? I think I think it's which is why I guess, you know, the DOE merit review now they they the two are now no longer together. So, it's I think it's it's not obvious that there is actually any serious venue that brings a bridge between those two communities.

speaker: Jordi Cabana

People just don't care enough?

speaker: Jenny Yang

And so I think it's just I don't know if it's I don't know I don't know why that is, but you know, you think about since we've had so much trouble getting selective selectivity for more complex products that that would be sort of the next step is can we take some of the things that we can make cleanly and use those as feedstocks for additional reduction reactions.

transcript: I think I think this field need I mean the whole field needs like a Tesla moment, right? I think or a Tesla effect, right? speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
transcript: Yeah, I think the I think one challenge is the the product, right, is is a giant reactor, right? Uh so so and and I think if you think about it, right, I think uh you know, uh this is like saying that I mean the advantage that you know, some of the other industries have is you can sort of sell something intermediate uh and make money and then slowly move. Maybe this is possible here also, but the the in order to compete, right, you you you need a a massive reactor which is uh which is when you can compete with other ways of making uh chemicals or fuels. So I think that's scale is maybe one one challenge that there maybe there are not easy intermediate products that could get us to to that scale. Um but I don't see a fundamental reason, right? I mean, I think there's no there's actually no real reason that you couldn't imagine that uh you know, we couldn't have uh you know, another uh sort of giant instigator that takes over this field and says, okay, we're we're going to go all in on this, right? We're going to raise a billion dollars, uh we're going to go all in, uh and and this is it, right? This is the problem of our generation.

speaker: Wilson Smith
transcript: I mean to answer that is you know, I don't think it's a matter of why can't we do certain things. I think it's directly a matter of the competition. There are already existing processes that are large scale that have a very cheap feedstock and relatively efficiently and stably can make something. So it's not that we can't make it's not that we're trying to make some product that's never been made before. The problem is the competition. It is so cheap and so large scale already that our I mean it's you know I I agree with Venkat. I mean there's not a thermodynamic or fundamental scientific reason we can't do these things, but in terms of cost, I mean even if you throw a billion dollars at it, it's still going to be way cheaper for Shell or Exxon to continue what they're doing, pay their carbon tax, and they will be just fine financially, which is you know, we have to remind ourselves that business is involved in this. So I think that the the biggest issue is that we're competing with existing technologies that have been around for a long time, are large scale, and very very cheap and efficient.
